Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 01:47PM dkmaustx wrote: My rad onc said not to use anything, also, before rads each day - no cream, powder, or whatever that would interfer with the radiation treatment. After the treatment I could use Aquaphor and Aloe gel, they aren't exactly deodorant, but I didn't go anywhere except home anyway.

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2007 02:59PM dkmaustx wrote: I always got the Neulasta shot the day after Chemo when I was on the A/C cycles. Maybe different regimens have different windows for the Neulasta.
Posts.Title: Neulastia lady4law lady4law

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2007 05:09PM - edited Dec 28, 2007 10:59PM by dkmaustx I don't see a GYN regularly, my Primary doc, a Family Practice Doctor, does all my check ups and PAP smears and such. I don't think I saw her at all during the diagnosis process after she sent me for my regular screening mammogram after my Annual check up last Dec. I had the mammo on Dec 5, an Ultra Sound on Dec 12, and a needle biopsy on Dec 19. The surgeon called me 2 days later and said we needed to talk the next morning and to bring someone with me. After the lumpectomy in early Jan 2007, the surgeon asked me which oncologist I wanted to go to. I found the closest cancer center to my house and picked one of those doctors. I liked him and everyone I met there. I think I went back to my Primary doc sometime in June when the cancer center found something they didn't handle in one of my tests.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2008 02:51PM - edited Jan 22, 2008 02:53PM by dkmaustx Siona, I was overwhelmed with all the info at first and decided to take it in smaller bits. I went one step at a time, reading just what I needed to know for that day or week. Chemo wasn't too bad for me; I was able get help for every side effect that I had. I'm glad that my husband was able to take me and pick me up, though.  I'm sorry your husband can't be with you in person as you are going through this. I hope you have a friend or other relative to go to appointments with you, though. It helps to have another pair of ears. As cmb said sometimes you just have to cry before you can move on. There are many people here ready to offer help and advice. I usually had a list of questions for my doctors. They were patient with me and answered all of them.
Posts.Title: just diagnosed siona siona

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2007 03:23PM dkmaustx wrote: My onologist said no dental cleaning during chemo, too. Luckily I had my teeth cleaned 2 days before my lumpectomy and wasn't due to for another until just after Chemo was done. All through Chemo my blood counts were at good levels and always back in the normal range before the next treatment. I scheduled my dental cleaning and check up 3 weeks after my last chemo, to make sure I'd be strong enough.
